title: Ford City father now faces trial in son's accidental shooting
content:
A Ford City man slated to get probation for his son's accidental shooting will instead stand trial because an Armstrong County judge says the man should serve jail time.
Christopher Bryan McNeely, 30, was scheduled to receive two years of probation for leaving two loaded handguns on his kitchen counter in August. His 6-year-old son was wounded when the boy's 9-year-old half-brother accidentally shot him.
The boy survived but was left with serious damage to his left arm.
At sentencing Tuesday, President Judge Kenneth G. Valasek asked McNeely's attorney, Timothy Kidd, whether McNeely was prepared to go to jail. Judges aren't bound to accept plea bargains.
“He wasn't ready to go to jail, so I filed a motion to vacate the plea,” Kidd said Wednesday.
McNeely is now scheduled to go to trial Sept. 12 on all original charges of reckless endangerment, two counts each of allowing a minor to have a firearm and endangering the welfare of children.
District Attorney Scott Andreassi said it's rare in the county for judges not to affirm plea bargains when presentence investigations recommend them.
“It's a very odd situation given that Judge Valasek ... admitted the co-defendant into the ARD program,” he said in a text.
Court records show that on July 7, McNeely's wife, Crista McNeely, accepted a form of probation for first-time offenders and was accepted into the accelerated rehabilitative disposition (ARD) program for six months.
Valasek wasn't available for comment.
Chuck Biedka is a Tribune-Review staff writer.
